items.title: How will Georgia's crisis over the contested presidency play out? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Mikheil Kavelashvili has been sworn in as President of Georgia on Sunday, despite allegations that the election was fraudulent. Kavelashvili is allied with the far-right Georgian Dream Party, which has close ties to Russia. Thousands of people gathered in the capital Tblisi to protest the inaguration. Georgia has seen months of political turmoil over plans by the Georgian Dream party to suspend membership talks with the EU. Georgia's main opposition groups say they don't recognize Kavelashvili as president. Georgias outgoing president has not formally conceded her office. What grounds does she have to challenge her successor's legitimacy? And how will this crisis over the contested presidency play out?

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Why we wouldn't see a president like Jimmy Carter today | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
During his term in office, Carter brokered a peace deal between Israel and Egypt known as the Camp David Accords, and presided over the Iran hostage crisis. He was the first US president to live to be a 100 years old.

items.title: South Korea plane crash: What do the experts say? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
South Korea is observing a week of national mourning after a jetliner crash killed 179 people. It's the deadliest plane crash ever on the country's soil. Only two people survived the disaster on Sunday, both were members of the crew. People have been paying their respects at a memorial in the city of Muan, where the plane went down. South Korea's acting president is also attending the ceremony. Investigators are now analyzing the flight data and comb the wreckage in search of bodies, and answers. Some experts have also criticized the airport's construction, having that solid wall at the end of the runway.

#SouthKorea #AirportCrash #Jejuair

items.title: Former US President Jimmy Carter dies at 100: What's his legacy? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Former US President Jimmy Carter has passed away in hospice care in his home town of Plains, Georgia at the age of 100. In a post on X, the Carter Center said that Jimmy Carter died peacefully, surrounded by his family. The former US president governed amid Cold War pressures, turbulent oil markets and social upheaval over racism, women's rights and America's global role. 

His achievements in office included brokering a landmark peace treaty between Israel and Egypt in 1978 known as the Camp David Accords. For that he would later win the Nobel Peace Prize. That Camp David experience inspired the post-presidential center where Carter would establish so much of his legacy, largely shaped by his work after leaving the presidency in 1981. 

He was the first US president to live to be a 100 years old. 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: New Georgian president sworn in as predecessor says he is not legitimate leader | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Georgia on Sunday inaugurated Mikheil Kavelashvili as the new president amid allegations his election was stolen. Kavelashvili, a hardline critic of the West and former a Manchester City footballer, was sworn in at a parliamentary ceremony. Georgia's outgoing pro-EU president has denounced Kavelashvili as illegitimate.

items.title: Jeju Air jet crash: Death toll rises to at least 151 people in South Korea | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
A passenger jet has crashed upon landing in South Korea, killing at least 151 people. The Jeju Air flight from Bangkok skidded off the runway at Muan International Airport, crashed into a barrier and burst into flames. 181 people were on board the flight. Only two people have been rescued from the tail section of the Boeing 737-800. Officials say there's little chance of finding other survivors, which would make it South Korea's worst aviation disaster. 

Chapter Breakdown
0:00 Jeju Air passenger jet crashes in South Korea, only two survivors confirmed
1:42 Jen Moon, Journalist at Muan International Airport, on what authorities know so far
4:24 Richard Levy, Aviation expert, on possible causes of crash

items.title: South Korea: Jeju Air plane skidded off runway, killing at least 47 people | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
A plane crashed at Muan International Airport in South Korea, killing at least 47 people, according to South Korean authorities. The Jeju Air flight with 181 people skidded off the runway and slammed into a wall before catching fire. At least two people have been rescued.  

The flight was flying back from Bangkok in Thailand, and the incident took place while it was landing. According to the emergency office and local media, the landing gear malfunctioned, causing the plane to run off the runway, hit a fence, and catch fire.

items.title: Syria authorities launch operation in Assad stronghold - Are loyalists a threat? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Syria's new administration is stepping up its campaign to track down members of the ousted regime of Bashar al-Assad. 

Over the weekend, security forces deployed to the Latakia region to flush out remnants of Assad militias and confiscate weapons and ammunition. Syria's new rulers have been working to assert their authority.

Assad has since fled to Moscow to escape the takeover.
